column1: Tolkien's language leaves some room for speculation. The first quote seems to describe a Balrog covered in shadow that appears winglike
column3: the second quoted passage seems to indicate that this Balrog had actual wings that were spread from wall to wall.

column1: [[Image:John Howe - Balrog 05.jpg|thumb|[[John Howe]] depicts a Balrog with wings.]]

The most common reference for winged Balrogs is the 'vast wings' language in "The Bridge of Khazad-dûm". The plain language here explicitly refers to 'wings.' Another Tolkien reference may be taken as evidence of Balrog wings:

column2: and they passed with winged speed over Hithlum
column3: and they came to Lammoth as a tempest of fire.|''[[Morgoth's Ring]]''
column4: "The Later Quenta Silmarillion: Of the Rape of the Silmarils"}}

column2: or a literal reference to physical wings - it is this issue over the verb 'to fly' which is mostly at the heart of the Balrog debate. Another
